Award.AwardTitle: Enhanced Flow Boiling Heat Transfer at Microscale for Stable, High Heat Flux Removal

Division.LongName: Div Of Chem, Bioeng, Env, & Transp Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
CBET-1236062
PI: Kandlikar

High heat flux removal while limiting the substrate temperature is critical in electronics cooling application. Current processor cooling demands are seen to reach a heat flux of 1 kW/cm2 while the device surface temperature needs to be low enough to keep the junction temperatures below 85 Â°C within the IC chip. Flow boiling in microchannels has been identified as a potential cooling technique to meet this cooling demand. However, the boiling instability and poor heat transfer performance during flow boiling in microchannels have been major impediments in realizing the desired cooling performance.

The project effort is directed specifically at developing a stable, high performance flow boiling system to meet the current electronics cooling demands. This will be accomplished by a novel open microchannel design with tapered manifolds. The open microchannel design provides a low resistance pathway for vapor while the liquid remains in contact with the substrate providing efficient cooling due nucleate and/or convective boiling. Further enhancements in heat transfer coefficient and critical heat flux (maximum possible heat flux under safe operation) will be achieved by adding offset strip-fins and nanowires respectively on the substrate. The tapered manifold provides an effective way to eliminate the flow boiling instability. These concepts have been validated in the preliminary experiments in the PI?s lab. The focus of the project will be to understand the basic mechanism of flow boiling in this configuration and significantly improve the heat transfer performance with water. In addition, FC87 and ethanol will also be investigated as working fluids. FC87 is a dielectric fluid that can be directly used in electronics cooling application. Ethanol is also a dielectric fluid and has a better heat transfer performance compared to FC87. Although ethanol is flammable, its superior performance may be weighed against the precautions needed in designing safe cooling systems. The work will be done by graduate and undergraduate students who will gain hand-on experience on conducting advanced research on microscale transport processes.

The major outcomes of the project will be developing a novel high heat flux removal system, understanding the basic heat transfer mechanisms during flow boiling at microscale, and educating undergraduate and graduate students. In addition, the students and PI working on the project will open interactions with area middle school students. They will be introduced to the emerging scientific areas including advanced heat transfer concepts, nanostructure development and research endeavors in quest of overcoming scientific barriers. Student from a local city school are scheduled to visit RIT once every week to interact with graduate students and learn from simulated projects that will be directed towards mimicking some of the key aspects of the planned research. The project will also be showcased to female students from high schools during their visits organized by WE (Woman in Engineering) volunteers at RIT.

ProgramReference.Text: REU SUPP-Res Exp for Ugrd Supp

POR.DRECONTENT:
The goal of this research was to develop a new flow boiling microchannel system which would provide significant performance enhancement (high heat dissipation) for electronics cooling application. The aim was to exceed a CHF value of 1 kW/cm2 using water. An innovative design of open microchannel with tapered manifold (Fig.1) was used to achieve this objective. The tapered gap above the microchannels provided an increasing cross-sectional area in the flow direction. This design allowed the nucleated bubbles to emerge from the microchannels, and expand in the gap region creating a separate liquid-vapor pathway system. Using a 6% taper and an inlet liquid flow Reynolds number of 1095, a record high critical heat flux (CHF) of 1.07 kW/cm2 with a heat transfer coefficient (HTC) of 295 kW/m2°C and a pressure drop of 30 kPa was recorded (Fig. 2).

 Further combining liquid inertia with tapered gap configuration provided a new mechanistic pathway for increasing heat transfer performance. The pressure recovery from the bubble expansion in the tapered gap provided a net reduction in pressure drop as compared to closed microchannels. The results showed that the high liquid inertia force can be used to expel the bubbles rapidly from the microchannels, improving the CHF and HTC, while the pressure drop is kept low. Similar boiling performance was achieved with ethanol, which was tested under gravity driven pumpless system. High speed visualization was conducted with images taken at 3000 - 10,000 frames per second to identify the underlying mechanism of bubble generation in the system (Fig. 3).

 Pressure drop modelling was undertaken using homogeneous flow model for variable flow cross-sectional area geometry. The model showed good prediction (MAE<30%) for microchannel chip with tapered manifolds. An additional area term was presented in the model to account for the tapered geometry due to its increasing flow cross-sectional area. This term additional term introduced a pressure recovery effect during the bubble expansion in the flow direction, and consequently, was critical in explaining the low pressure drop observed experimentally.

The award over the duration of three years has supported 10 undergraduate students, with half of them being women or minorities and providing them with invaluable hands-on research experience. The PI also developed a new outreach program, Beyond 9.8, in which a team of sixteen faculty members at RIT provide a three-hour, hands-on activity to the visiting 6th grade students from Franklin Roosevelt Middle School #43 from Rochester city school district serving minority and underprivileged students. Over 10 journal and conference papers have been published discussing this work. The PI has given three plenary talks and visited six universities as part of the graduate seminar series.

The project resulted in overcoming the shortcomings of a conventional microchannel system and provided exceptional heat transfer performance with CHF exceeding 1 kW/cm2 and a concurrent HTC of 295 kW/m2°C with a low pressure drop of 30 kPa. The intellectual contribution combined with broader impact in the area of STEM education and diverse student body involvement were some of the exceptional outcomes of this project.  

 


Last Modified: 11/11/2015
Modified by: Satish G Kandlikar

The project resulted in overcoming the shortcomings of a conventional microchannel system and provided exceptional heat transfer performance with CHF exceeding 1 kW/cm2 and a concurrent HTC of 295 kW/m2°C with a low pressure drop of 30 kPa. The intellectual contribution combined with broader impact in the area of STEM education and diverse student body involvement were some of the exceptional outcomes of this project.
